column4: First, you need to make the repo available internally, like at MyServer.local, on an HTTP server.  Second, you need to put a deb line for MyServer.local in the sources.list file of the client computers.
If you are doing new intallations, then you need to specify MyServer.local at the choose a mirror dialog.
all i care about is will dist-upgrade work. i already have the jaunty repo and it works jsut fine.
It will work the same from a local mirror as a regular *.ubuntu.com mirror.
Console VTs are different than ptys inside an X11 environment.  What are you trying to do?
trying to detect what vt is active. you know - ctrl+alt+F[0-12]?
Why?  Describe what you're trying to accomplish.
chvt to a specific VT when the VT is changed off
I'm working on a kiosk system

Console VTs stay 'active' in the background.  From userland, they behave no differently in the foreground or background.  You probably need to peek a kernel value from /proc or /sys, which means that you need to read the kernel Documentation/.
well I know they're still ... eh ... 'live'. but only one can be shown on the display at the time. I want to lock it to a specific one.
Consider using one VT and using `screen` to front your kiosk.  `screen` is easier to script, and is more likely to be portable.
the problem is that when they switch away from the main kiosk VT, they can log in to the shells in the other VTs
Your security model is broken.  Disable the unused VTs and/or jail the untrusted users and/or chroot your users.
There are a variety of ways to handle untrusted users.  You may want to look at things like the LTSP.

chroot can't do X last I checked, but also I want to be able to lock someone out of their X session. my idea is to switch them to another VT and then stop them from changing back, then once I'm done locking them out change back.
You're doing something for which several solutions are available.  Don't reinvent the wheel -- go do some reading on system hardening and handling untrusted sessions.
ok, what would you recommend I google to start this?
LTSP,  maybe SELinux.  Also check some userland solutions like the kiosk plugins for Firefox.
It is not possible to get a 1-to-1 replacement for console behavior in Linux vice your existing Windows environment.  The unix-style way to kick a user is to `kill` their login process.
LTSP was build specifically for classroom environments.  Go there.  You are certainly duplicating work that is already done and available.
this is not a thin client situation >>>
X11 doesn't work that way.  It doesn't matter.  The X head can be local or remote, and you'll get the same result.
Linux is not Windows.
